summary: This document is a chain of emails from September-October 2020 between Assistant United States Attorneys from the Southern District of New York and defense attorney Jill Greenfield. They are coordinating logistics for a potential in-person interview in London with Greenfield's client, who is a witness or victim in the Epstein investigation, discussing dates, team size, COVID-19 protocols, and travel approvals.

persons.name: Jill Greenfield
persons.context: Attorney representing a client who is a witness/victim in the Epstein investigation. She is coordinating with the U.S. Attorney's office to schedule an interview with her client in London, advocating for her client's comfort regarding the number of interviewers.

persons.name: Louise Scott
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence between Jill Greenfield and the U.S. Attorney's office, likely a colleague or assistant.

connections.description: Greenfield is representing the client, communicating the client's preferences (e.g., limiting the number of interviewers) to the prosecutors.
Professional correspondence coordinating the logistics for a witness/victim interview as part of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Proposed Interview Dates in London
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's office proposes these dates for successive meetings with Jill Greenfield's client in London.

events.title: Alternative Proposed Interview Dates
events.description: Alternative dates proposed by the U.S. Attorney's office for the London interviews.

events.title: Previous Video Call with Client
events.description: Mention of a prior video conference call between the investigation team (prosecutors and FBI agents) and Jill Greenfield's client.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Riverbank House, 2 Swan Lane, London EC4R 3TT (Fieldfisher office)
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively seeking to interview a witness/victim (represented by Jill Greenfield) in London in October 2020 as part of the Epstein investigation.
The witness/victim expressed discomfort with a large interview team, preferring only two interviewers present.
The coordination occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic, with discussions about travel restrictions, quarantine waivers, and potential testing for the U.S. team.
The investigation team planning to travel consisted of at least one Assistant U.S. Attorney and two FBI personnel (a Special Agent and a Task Force Officer).
The emails reveal standard prosecutorial diligence in witness coordination, including seeking client comfort and navigating international travel logistics for government employees.
